values.description:
When creating an AODV routing algorithm I ran into the issue where a node using the SendTo message using the built in broadcast mechanism will send a message to itself along with all its neighbors.  This causes a rebroadcasting nightmare.

This patch fixes that and also causes the Neighbors method to NOT include a node inside its own list of neighbors.
values.title: Don't mark myself as one of my neighbors.

summary.raw:
When creating an AODV routing algorithm I ran into the issue where a node using the SendTo message using the built in broadcast mechanism will send a message to itself along with all its neighbors.  This causes a rebroadcasting nightmare.

This patch fixes that and also causes the Neighbors method to NOT include a node inside its own list of neighbors.
summary.html:
When creating an AODV routing algorithm I ran into the issue where a node using the SendTo message using the built in broadcast mechanism will send a message to itself along with all its neighbors. This causes a rebroadcasting nightmare.

This patch fixes that and also causes the Neighbors method to NOT include a node inside its own list of neighbors.

summary.html: Motivated by pull request #51.

values.description: This pull request will degrade communications when the data throughput increases over a given threshold. We set `<comms_data_rate_max>` as the maximum data rate allowed among robots communicating over the same network segment (in bps).
values.title: Add maximum data rate parameter to communication model

summary.raw: This pull request will degrade communications when the data throughput increases over a given threshold. We set `<comms_data_rate_max>` as the maximum data rate allowed among robots communicating over the same network segment (in bps).
summary.html: This pull request will degrade communications when the data throughput increases over a given threshold. We set <comms_data_rate_max> as the maximum data rate allowed among robots communicating over the same network segment (in bps).

values.title: Add cmake code to get hg hash

summary.html:
This change will try to invoke hg identify to get the hash of the current working copy. If it fails, it sets the version to "unknown".

To use the hash in code, include the config header and refer to SWARM_HASH_VERSION (it's a string), e.g.:

#include "swarm/config.hh"
...
std::cout "The hash version is: " << SWARM_HASH_VERSION << std::endl;

values.description:
`master.erb` contains one function per world file to be generated. There are instructions inside the file for adding new worlds.

As an example, I removed `complete.world.erb` and generated `complete.world` using this new strategy.

How to test this pull request:

* Clean your build directory.
* Compile and install (don't forget to compile and install the example directory)
* Execute:

```
#!python

gazebo worlds/complete.world
```
values.title: Automatic world generation based on parameters

values.description:
Adds a header to the log file containing:

* Swarm version.
* Gazebo version.
* Random seed.

I updated `Logger_TEST`, `LogParser.hh` and `swarmlog`.

For testing this PR, you should create a new log file, and then you can run:

```
#!python

swarmlog --info -f ~/.swarm/log/<YOUR_TIMESTAMP>/swarm.log
```

Note: this PR is built atop pull request #55, which should be merged first. [Here](#!/osrf/swarm/branches/compare/log_header%0Dadd_hg_hash_hook#diff) is a better diff.

values.description:
Invoke the protobuf compiler to produce Python bindings, in addition to the current C++ bindings.  Install the resulting bindings.

Note that we have to also do Python generation for the Gazebo messages, because Gazebo doesn't do that (but Gazebo is kind enough to install the `.proto` files and point us to their location, which makes this step easy to do).

To test that this is working, start python and:

    import swarm
    l = swarm.log_entry_pb2.LogEntry()

From there you can instantiate and manipulate any of the swarm or gazebo protobuf messages.

Next I'll use this Python support to write a log-parsing / -plotting tool.

**Edit**: I added an example tool that uses the Python message API to parse a swarm log, compute some simple statistics, and output a `.csv` file.
values.title: Add Python message generation

summary.raw:
Invoke the protobuf compiler to produce Python bindings, in addition to the current C++ bindings.  Install the resulting bindings.

Note that we have to also do Python generation for the Gazebo messages, because Gazebo doesn't do that (but Gazebo is kind enough to install the `.proto` files and point us to their location, which makes this step easy to do).

To test that this is working, start python and:

    import swarm
    l = swarm.log_entry_pb2.LogEntry()

From there you can instantiate and manipulate any of the swarm or gazebo protobuf messages.

Next I'll use this Python support to write a log-parsing / -plotting tool.

**Edit**: I added an example tool that uses the Python message API to parse a swarm log, compute some simple statistics, and output a `.csv` file.
summary.html:
Invoke the protobuf compiler to produce Python bindings, in addition to the current C++ bindings. Install the resulting bindings.

Note that we have to also do Python generation for the Gazebo messages, because Gazebo doesn't do that (but Gazebo is kind enough to install the .proto files and point us to their location, which makes this step easy to do).

To test that this is working, start python and:

import swarm
l = swarm.log_entry_pb2.LogEntry()

From there you can instantiate and manipulate any of the swarm or gazebo protobuf messages.

Next I'll use this Python support to write a log-parsing / -plotting tool.

Edit: I added an example tool that uses the Python message API to parse a swarm log, compute some simple statistics, and output a .csv file.

values.description:
This patch generates world files based on the following parameters:

* Search area (Km): [2x2, 10x10, 25x25].
* Vegetation density (manually placed, nothing fancy): [low, medium, high].
* Number of vehicles of each type: [10, 25, 50].

All world files share the same heightmap based on a region of 25x25 Km of Camp Roberts.

We run all possible combinations and create a world file with each set of parameters.

~~Note: this PR is built atop pull request #60, which should be merged first. [Here](#!/osrf/swarm/branches/compare/worlds%0Dreset#diff) is a better diff.~~
values.title: Test worlds

summary.raw:
This patch generates world files based on the following parameters:

* Search area (Km): [2x2, 10x10, 25x25].
* Vegetation density (manually placed, nothing fancy): [low, medium, high].
* Number of vehicles of each type: [10, 25, 50].

All world files share the same heightmap based on a region of 25x25 Km of Camp Roberts.

We run all possible combinations and create a world file with each set of parameters.

~~Note: this PR is built atop pull request #60, which should be merged first. [Here](#!/osrf/swarm/branches/compare/worlds%0Dreset#diff) is a better diff.~~
summary.html:
This patch generates world files based on the following parameters:

  • Search area (Km): [2x2, 10x10, 25x25].
  • Vegetation density (manually placed, nothing fancy): [low, medium, high].
  • Number of vehicles of each type: [10, 25, 50].

All world files share the same heightmap based on a region of 25x25 Km of Camp Roberts.

We run all possible combinations and create a world file with each set of parameters.

Note: this PR is built atop pull request #60, which should be merged first. Here is a better diff.

values.description:
Based on feedback from the teams:

If a vehicle moves at 20m/s and we assume 20 Km as the maximum distance between a vehicle and the BOO, it'll take 1000 seconds to reach the BOO.

* Rotor: 20mm focal length,  ~84 degree field of view
* Ground: 50mm focal length, ~40 degree field of view
* Fixed: 200mm focal length,  ~10 degree field of view

Also fixes the ruby parameter errors.

values.description:
See issue #9.

We were using the gazebo RandomVelocityPlugin for controlling the lost person. This plugin does not adjust the model position based on the terrain. I copied a simplified version of the Gazebo plugin in our example/LostPersonControllerPlugin.

For testing, just run:

```
#!python

gazebo worlds/ground_easy_4.world
```

And you shouldn't see the lost person under the terrain as before.

values.description:
See issue #08.

Adds some hysteresis to false positives. There are two new constants in RobotPlugin:

* `cameraFalsePositiveDurationMin`: Minimum length of a false positive in seconds.
* `cameraFalsePositiveDurationMax`: Maximum length of a false positive in seconds.

Every time a false positive is created, we associate a data structure with the observed model. This structure contains:

* Time at which the false positive should expire.
* Model that replaces the real observed model (this is the false positive).

In the future, if we observe the same model again and we are in false positive period, we'll replace the observed model with the same false positive.
values.title: Fix issue #08

summary.raw:
See issue #08.

Adds some hysteresis to false positives. There are two new constants in RobotPlugin:

* `cameraFalsePositiveDurationMin`: Minimum length of a false positive in seconds.
* `cameraFalsePositiveDurationMax`: Maximum length of a false positive in seconds.

Every time a false positive is created, we associate a data structure with the observed model. This structure contains:

* Time at which the false positive should expire.
* Model that replaces the real observed model (this is the false positive).

In the future, if we observe the same model again and we are in false positive period, we'll replace the observed model with the same false positive.
summary.html:
See issue #08.

Adds some hysteresis to false positives. There are two new constants in RobotPlugin:

  • cameraFalsePositiveDurationMin: Minimum length of a false positive in seconds.
  • cameraFalsePositiveDurationMax: Maximum length of a false positive in seconds.

Every time a false positive is created, we associate a data structure with the observed model. This structure contains:

  • Time at which the false positive should expire.
  • Model that replaces the real observed model (this is the false positive).

In the future, if we observe the same model again and we are in false positive period, we'll replace the observed model with the same false positive.

values.description:
See issue #13.

Send an ACK from the BOO to the robot after processing a `FOUND` message. The ACK message includes a code with the result of the `FOUND` command.

The ACK is a unicast message targeted to the robot that requested the `FOUND` message on the default port.
values.title: Fix issue #13

summary.raw:
See issue #13.

Send an ACK from the BOO to the robot after processing a `FOUND` message. The ACK message includes a code with the result of the `FOUND` command.

The ACK is a unicast message targeted to the robot that requested the `FOUND` message on the default port.
summary.html:
See issue #13.

Send an ACK from the BOO to the robot after processing a FOUND message. The ACK message includes a code with the result of the FOUND command.

The ACK is a unicast message targeted to the robot that requested the FOUND message on the default port.

values.description: This copies the `RobotPlugin::MapQuery` into `LostPersonPlugin`. It's code duplication, but this is a quick and easy solution.
values.title: Lost person plugin map query

summary.html: This copies the RobotPlugin::MapQuery into LostPersonPlugin. It's code duplication, but this is a quick and easy solution.

values.description:
Two main changes:

* Update sensors in the RobotPlugin at a lower rate than the plugin rate. Also, the updates are not synchronized, meaning that not all the sensor updates happen at the same time across each RobotPlugin.
* Update visibility and neighbor information at a lower rate than the plugin.

There is one new SDF parameter that can be used in the RobotPlugin:

* `<sensor_update_rate>`: Frequency of sensor updates. 20 Hz is the default value.

There is one new SDF parameter that can be used in the BrokerPlugin (inside the `<comms_model>` block):

* `<update_rate>`: Frequency of visibility and neighbor updates. 0.5 Hz is the default value.

How to test:

Load gazebo with `final_01_02_low_50.world` with and without this patch. Compare the real-time factor between the two versions. You should observe a better number in the version that uses this patch.
values.title: Increase performance

Two main changes:

* Update sensors in the RobotPlugin at a lower rate than the plugin rate. Also, the updates are not synchronized, meaning that not all the sensor updates happen at the same time across each RobotPlugin.
* Update visibility and neighbor information at a lower rate than the plugin.

There is one new SDF parameter that can be used in the RobotPlugin:

* `<sensor_update_rate>`: Frequency of sensor updates. 20 Hz is the default value.

There is one new SDF parameter that can be used in the BrokerPlugin (inside the `<comms_model>` block):

* `<update_rate>`: Frequency of visibility and neighbor updates. 0.5 Hz is the default value.

How to test:

Load gazebo with `final_01_02_low_50.world` with and without this patch. Compare the real-time factor between the two versions. You should observe a better number in the version that uses this patch.
summary.html:
Two main changes:

  • Update sensors in the RobotPlugin at a lower rate than the plugin rate. Also, the updates are not synchronized, meaning that not all the sensor updates happen at the same time across each RobotPlugin.
  • Update visibility and neighbor information at a lower rate than the plugin.

There is one new SDF parameter that can be used in the RobotPlugin:

  • <sensor_update_rate>: Frequency of sensor updates. 20 Hz is the default value.

There is one new SDF parameter that can be used in the BrokerPlugin (inside the <comms_model> block):

  • <update_rate>: Frequency of visibility and neighbor updates. 0.5 Hz is the default value.

How to test:

Load gazebo with final_01_02_low_50.world with and without this patch. Compare the real-time factor between the two versions. You should observe a better number in the version that uses this patch.

values.description:
Copies the RobotPlugin::Pose() into LostPersonPlugin.

Note that the GPS doesn't have noise. I don't think we need to add noise here, this is a helper function that the lost person model will use to understand its surroundings and take a decision based on true data.

Note that the GPS doesn't have noise. I don't think we need to add noise here, this is a helper function that the lost person model will use to understand its surroundings and take a decision based on true data.
summary.html:
Copies the RobotPlugin::Pose() into LostPersonPlugin.

Note that the GPS doesn't have noise. I don't think we need to add noise here, this is a helper function that the lost person model will use to understand its surroundings and take a decision based on true data.

values.description: I introduced a bug in pull request #72. When the number of robots is not big enough, the variables `CommsModel::visibilityUpdatesPerCycle` and `CommsModel::neighborUpdatesPerCycle` were `0`. This bug caused that the visibilityMap and the list of neighbors didn't update.
values.title: Fix comms model issue

summary.raw: I introduced a bug in pull request #72. When the number of robots is not big enough, the variables `CommsModel::visibilityUpdatesPerCycle` and `CommsModel::neighborUpdatesPerCycle` were `0`. This bug caused that the visibilityMap and the list of neighbors didn't update.
summary.html: I introduced a bug in pull request #72. When the number of robots is not big enough, the variables CommsModel::visibilityUpdatesPerCycle and CommsModel::neighborUpdatesPerCycle were 0. This bug caused that the visibilityMap and the list of neighbors didn't update.

values.description:
This is a fix for the following problem:

1. Compile and install the Swarm libraries.
1. Compile and install the `example/` directory.
1. Run gazebo (everything is OK):
 
```
#!python

gazebo worlds/lost_person.world --verbose
```

1. Make some change in `example/LostPersonControllerPlugin.cc`.
1. Recompile and install the `example/` directory.
1. Run gazebo (you should get an error):
 
```
#!python

gazebo worlds/lost_person.world --verbose
```
You should get the following error:


```
#!python

[Err] [Plugin.hh:165] Failed to load plugin libLostPersonControllerPlugin.so: /home/caguero/local/lib/libLostPersonControllerPlugin.so: undefined symbol: _ZN5swarm16LostPersonPlugin4LoadEN5boost10shared_ptrIN6gazebo7physics5ModelEEESt10shared_ptrIN3sdf7ElementEE
```

This patch should fix it.
values.title: Fix lost person problem

You should get the following error:

This patch should fix it.

values.description:
We needed to update the way we create the visibility map for logging. 

Now, the variable `visibilityMsg` that we use for logging the visibility map is prepopulated. The only thing we have to do every time something changes in the comms model is to update the CommsStatus field of the vehicles affected.
values.title: Update visibility map logging

summary.raw:
We needed to update the way we create the visibility map for logging. 

Now, the variable `visibilityMsg` that we use for logging the visibility map is prepopulated. The only thing we have to do every time something changes in the comms model is to update the CommsStatus field of the vehicles affected.
summary.html:
We needed to update the way we create the visibility map for logging.

Now, the variable visibilityMsg that we use for logging the visibility map is prepopulated. The only thing we have to do every time something changes in the comms model is to update the CommsStatus field of the vehicles affected.

values.description:
Install some scripts for automatic report generation.

Instructions:

* Install gnuplot:

```
#!python

sudo apt-get install gnuplot python-protobuf
```

* Make sure that you update your PYTHONPATH if you're not installing the Swarm files in a default location. E.g.:
 
``` 
#!python
 
export PYTHONPATH=/home/caguero/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/
```

* Run a Swarm experiment with logging enabled. E.g.:


```
#!python

SWARM_LOG=1 gazebo worlds/complete_10.world
```

* Generate a report using `swarm_generate_report`. E.g.:

```
#!python

swarm_generate_report /home/caguero/.swarm/log/2015-11-18T15\:58\:44.954493/swarm.log /tmp/report1
```

The first argument is the path to the Swarm log file and the second parameter is the new directory where the reported will be created. This should generate three files:

* report.pdf : The report.
* swarm.csv: Text file with all relevant information grouped by columns.
* swarm_summary.tex: Summary of the report used to generate the PDF.

There are some fields in the report that will appear as `unknown`. This will be fixed in another pull request that will probably require to add more fields to the log files.
values.title: Generate report - Part1

summary.raw:
Install some scripts for automatic report generation.

Instructions:

* Install gnuplot:

```
#!python

sudo apt-get install gnuplot python-protobuf
```

* Make sure that you update your PYTHONPATH if you're not installing the Swarm files in a default location. E.g.:
 
``` 
#!python
 
export PYTHONPATH=/home/caguero/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/
```

* Run a Swarm experiment with logging enabled. E.g.:


```
#!python

SWARM_LOG=1 gazebo worlds/complete_10.world
```

* Generate a report using `swarm_generate_report`. E.g.:

```
#!python

swarm_generate_report /home/caguero/.swarm/log/2015-11-18T15\:58\:44.954493/swarm.log /tmp/report1
```

The first argument is the path to the Swarm log file and the second parameter is the new directory where the reported will be created. This should generate three files:

* report.pdf : The report.
* swarm.csv: Text file with all relevant information grouped by columns.
* swarm_summary.tex: Summary of the report used to generate the PDF.

There are some fields in the report that will appear as `unknown`. This will be fixed in another pull request that will probably require to add more fields to the log files.
summary.html:
Install some scripts for automatic report generation.

Instructions:

  • Install gnuplot:
sudo apt-get install gnuplot python-protobuf
  • Make sure that you update your PYTHONPATH if you're not installing the Swarm files in a default location. E.g.:
export PYTHONPATH=/home/caguero/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/
  • Run a Swarm experiment with logging enabled. E.g.:
SWARM_LOG=1 gazebo worlds/complete_10.world
  • Generate a report using swarm_generate_report. E.g.:
swarm_generate_report /home/caguero/.swarm/log/2015-11-18T15\:58\:44.954493/swarm.log /tmp/report1

The first argument is the path to the Swarm log file and the second parameter is the new directory where the reported will be created. This should generate three files:

  • report.pdf : The report.
  • swarm.csv: Text file with all relevant information grouped by columns.
  • swarm_summary.tex: Summary of the report used to generate the PDF.

There are some fields in the report that will appear as unknown. This will be fixed in another pull request that will probably require to add more fields to the log files.

Resolves issue #17.

values.description: We created two different BOO plugins in pull request #85: one BOO base plugin and one BOO controller plugin. We loaded `libBooControllerPlugin` in the integration tests. I think we should load `libSwarmBooPlugin` for the tests. The tests shouldn't require the plugins that are compiled in the example directory.
values.title: Load libSwarmBooPlugin in integration tests

summary.raw: We created two different BOO plugins in pull request #85: one BOO base plugin and one BOO controller plugin. We loaded `libBooControllerPlugin` in the integration tests. I think we should load `libSwarmBooPlugin` for the tests. The tests shouldn't require the plugins that are compiled in the example directory.
summary.html: We created two different BOO plugins in pull request #85: one BOO base plugin and one BOO controller plugin. We loaded libBooControllerPlugin in the integration tests. I think we should load libSwarmBooPlugin for the tests. The tests shouldn't require the plugins that are compiled in the example directory.

values.description:
Include all the configuration parameters of an experiment in the log header and use it in the PDF report.

Now, the PDF should have all the `Configuration` section complete. Note that you need to set the environment variable `SWARM_TEAMNAME` if you want to include your team name in the log file. [This related tutorial](#!/osrf/swarm/wiki/Tutorial_14-Generate_reports) has been updated to include this detail.

The report has a new section `Completion` with `Unknown` fields. These fields will be addressed in a future pull request related with scoring.

For testing, just generate a new log file and generate a report following the instructions detailed in [the tutorial](#!/osrf/swarm/wiki/Tutorial_14-Generate_reports).
values.title: Generate report - Part2

summary.html:
Include all the configuration parameters of an experiment in the log header and use it in the PDF report.

Now, the PDF should have all the Configuration section complete. Note that you need to set the environment variable SWARM_TEAMNAME if you want to include your team name in the log file. This related tutorial has been updated to include this detail.

The report has a new section Completion with Unknown fields. These fields will be addressed in a future pull request related with scoring.

For testing, just generate a new log file and generate a report following the instructions detailed in the tutorial.

values.description:
This PR adds the "Completion" section to the PDF report including score. 

The score is a value between 0 and 1 (higher is better) and is calculated as follow:

* If you don't find the lost person your score is 0.
* The elapsed time weights 80% of the score. The elapsed time is normalized using the `maximum_allowed_time` for this world. This parameter is included in each world file and hand tuned.
* The number of wrong `FOUND` reports weights 20% of the score. If you don't send any incorrect reports, you'll get the maximum score in this block. The number of wrong reports is normalized given a parameter `maximum_wrong_reports` included in each world file and hand tuned. The default value is `20`.

How to test it:

Run a new simulation with logging enabled and follow [this tutorial](#!/osrf/swarm/wiki/Tutorial_14-Generate_reports) for generating the PDF report. You should see the new section in the report.
values.title: Generate report - Part3

summary.raw:
This PR adds the "Completion" section to the PDF report including score. 

The score is a value between 0 and 1 (higher is better) and is calculated as follow:

* If you don't find the lost person your score is 0.
* The elapsed time weights 80% of the score. The elapsed time is normalized using the `maximum_allowed_time` for this world. This parameter is included in each world file and hand tuned.
* The number of wrong `FOUND` reports weights 20% of the score. If you don't send any incorrect reports, you'll get the maximum score in this block. The number of wrong reports is normalized given a parameter `maximum_wrong_reports` included in each world file and hand tuned. The default value is `20`.

How to test it:

Run a new simulation with logging enabled and follow [this tutorial](#!/osrf/swarm/wiki/Tutorial_14-Generate_reports) for generating the PDF report. You should see the new section in the report.
summary.html:
This PR adds the "Completion" section to the PDF report including score.

The score is a value between 0 and 1 (higher is better) and is calculated as follow:

  • If you don't find the lost person your score is 0.
  • The elapsed time weights 80% of the score. The elapsed time is normalized using the maximum_allowed_time for this world. This parameter is included in each world file and hand tuned.
  • The number of wrong FOUND reports weights 20% of the score. If you don't send any incorrect reports, you'll get the maximum score in this block. The number of wrong reports is normalized given a parameter maximum_wrong_reports included in each world file and hand tuned. The default value is 20.

How to test it:

Run a new simulation with logging enabled and follow this tutorial for generating the PDF report. You should see the new section in the report.

values.description: Removed `BrokerClient` to prevent hitting the virtual table for every `OnMsgReceived` call. Also unthrottled the worlds.

values.description:
Big thanks to @esquires for this update to the fixed wing model. Rolling a fixed wing vehicle should cause it to turn without dipping.

Fixed wing vehicles will now also start 10m off the ground.
values.title: Update the roll for fixed wing

values.description:
* Max step size changed to `0.1` to increase performance.
* The worlds now use the `$max_step_size` variable declared in `master.erb`. 
* The log header includes the `max_step_size` used during the simulation.
* The script that processes the log file uses the `max_step_size` included in the log file.
values.title: Changes in the code to easily modify max_step_size.

summary.raw:
* Max step size changed to `0.1` to increase performance.
* The worlds now use the `$max_step_size` variable declared in `master.erb`. 
* The log header includes the `max_step_size` used during the simulation.
* The script that processes the log file uses the `max_step_size` included in the log file.
summary.html:
• Max step size changed to 0.1 to increase performance.
  • The worlds now use the $max_step_size variable declared in master.erb.
  • The log header includes the max_step_size used during the simulation.
  • The script that processes the log file uses the max_step_size included in the log file.

values.description:
The most important part of this pull request is the `run_swarm.rb` script. 

* View the command line options: `run_swarm.rb -h`

* Example usage that clears existing log files, has a maximum duration of 2 hours for each test, uses 6 processes, stores data in `/data/swarm_logs/<time-stamped-directory-auto-created>`, repeats each test 4 times, and uses `nps` as the teams name.

```
run_swarm.rb -c -t 7200 -j 6 -d /data/swarm_logs -r 4 --team nps
```
values.title: Improve performance, added a script to run multiple tests in parallel
